entry.title: Tonan Maru No. 3 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Japanese vessel Tonan Maru No. 3 (pictured), sunk in a 17 February 1944 air raid, was raised seven years later and returned to service as a whaling factory ship?

entry.title: Eva Siracká (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Eva Siracká remained the president of the League Against Cancer, citing the reign of Elizabeth II as the reason?

entry.title: Royalton Hotel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the lobby of the Royalton Hotel was once compared to an ocean liner?

entry.title: Mark Wetjen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Mark Wetjen was a top advisor for Sam Bankman-Fried, the former CEO of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, during an aggressive lobbying campaign at the United States Congress?

entry.title: captured (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although Greek forces captured the Aegean island of Chios in January 1913, its annexation to Greece was not finalized until 1923?

entry.title: Charlotte Payne (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 2022, Briton Charlotte Payne broke the world record for a hammer throw by a deaf woman by almost 5 metres (16 ft)?

entry.title: Arab Orthodox Movement (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Arab Orthodox Movement aims to Arabize the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate of Jerusalem, a church whose laity is mostly Arab but is led by Greek clergy?

entry.title: Mittens (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Mittens was a chess-playing "cat"?
